Award.AwardTitle: Size Effect on the Evolution of Kirkendall Pores in Ti-Coated Ni Wires
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract:

Thermal shape memory alloys (SMAs) are an interesting type of material that can be deformed and recover their initial shape upon heating. In particular, one of the most commonly known SMAs is Nitinol, which is an alloy with a near 1:1 ratio of nickel and titanium (i.e. NiTi). Because of this shape recovery behavior, Nitinol is commonly used for applications such as actuators or switches. Additionally, NiTi is a biocompatible material and, hence, can be used for a variety of biomedical applications from stents to bone implants. While traditional bulk Nitinol has proven very useful thus far, it can be further improved by introducing open porosity to enhance the properties in a variety of ways. For example, by including open porosity, the surface area to volume ratio increases, thereby increasing the heating and cooling efficiency leading to faster response times of the thermal shape memory effect. Another example from the biomedical perspective is that the open porosity allows for ingrowth of bone aiding in the integration of the NiTi implant. However, manufacturing such NiTi structures with open porosity is challenging due to the high melting point and reactive nature of NiTi. One way to overcome this issue is to fabricate porous structures from pure Ni and then deposit Ti on them such that, once homogenized, NiTi structures with shape memory behavior will be formed. This research will focus on transforming pure Ni wires into three-dimensional NiTi wire-woven structures. This project will provide various outreach opportunities including at local elementary schools, demonstrating the shape memory behavior of NiTi to introduce students to the discipline of materials science. We will also be creating a series of YouTube videos that will discuss the processing and shape recovery properties of NiTi structures.


Technical Abstract:

Porous NiTi structures offer a combination of shape-memory behavior, low stiffness, and high surface area useful for applications such as actuators, bone implants, and dampers. The most common synthesis method for porous NiTi - self-propagating high-temperature synthesis where mixed Ni and Ti powders are reacted uncontrollably - resulting in undesirable intermetallic phases and uncontrolled Kirkendall pores. We seek to investigate a novel approach where controlled interdiffusion in Ti-coated Ni wires forms near equiatomic NiTi alloys with shape-memory or superelastic behavior. This project aims at understanding the wire size effect on the Ni-Ti interdiffusion behavior and Kirkendall pore evolution. Specifically, as the wire diameter (i.e. its volume-to-surface ratio) decreases, we expect a transition from (i) numerous Kirkendall pores in the cross-section (bulk behavior) for large wires, to (ii) a single pore in the cross-section for thinner wires, to (iii) no pores for very thin wires, as vacancies diffuse to the surface instead of forming pores. To this end, we will be conducting a systematic study that explores the mechanisms and kinetics of Ni-Ti interdiffusion and Kirkendall pore evolution as a function of wire diameter, ranging from 10 to 200 Âµm. Pure Ni wires will be coated with Ti via pack cementation and subsequently homogenized while capturing the evolution (size, fraction, location) of the various intermediate and final phases (NiTi2, NiTi, Ni3Ti) and the Kirkendall pores. Wires will be characterized using both ex situ metallographic techniques and in situ X-ray tomography. Knowledge gained from these experiments will be applied to the fabrication of NiTi (1D) wires, (2D) springs, and (3D) woven scaffolds. For verification of the experimental results and eventual prediction of optimized interdiffusion parameters, a phase-field model will be developed to predict the microstructural evolution (phases and pores) during coating and homogenization. Also, finite-element models based on tomographic data will be developed to investigate the effect of Kirkendall pores on mechanical (shape-memory and superelastic) behavior.

Various researchers have demonstrated that Kirkendall pores can be harnessed to produce hollow structures. However, there has not yet been a systematic investigation on the effect of sample size and spatial confinement on the Kirkendall porosity formation and stability. A fundamental understanding of the sample size effect (linked to the ratio of vacancy diffusion distance to wire diameter) on Ni-Ti interdiffusion behavior and Kirkendall porosity will serve as a guideline for choosing appropriate processing conditions for production of porous NiTi structures. It will also provide more general insight into the mechanisms and optimization of using the Kirkendall effect for creating such hollow structures in other metallic systems. Moreover, the experiments performed and models developed in this project will enable manufacturing of wire- or spring-based micro-architectured NiTi structures with unique shape-recovery properties, which are impossible to produce at such small length scales via current wire drawing and weaving methods. Such woven structures will be suitable for actuation, damping, and biomedical applications, taking advantage of improved permeability, increased surface area, lower stiffness and high shape memory and superelasticity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

 

Nickel-titanium alloys have important uses in biomedical implants, thermal actuators, and other applications as they have both superelastic and shape memory behaviors. By introducing porosity into NiTi alloys, the stiffness and surface area of the material can be tuned, which may further improve performance in various applications (e.g., improved biocompatibility, enhanced actuator response). Therefore, it becomes critical to produce NiTi alloys with controllable levels of porosity in a repeatable manner.

 

Such porous NiTi materials can be produced by the pack titanization process, a type of chemical vapor deposition. In this work, we studied the formation of Kirkendall porosity during the titanization process and subsequent homogenization. Starting from pure Ni microwires of various diameters, Ti was deposited onto the surface of the wires. The wires were then homogenized to create near-equiatomic NiTi alloys. The intrinsic diffusivities of Ni and Ti are mismatched, and, thus, induces a significant flux of vacancies in the direction opposite the faster moving component, which is referred to as the Kirkendall effect. Experimentally, this leads to a local supersaturation of vacancies that condense to form so-called Kirkendall pores. The microwire geometry confines the vacancy flux, and therefore the porosity tends to coalesce into a central channel, creating a microtube. However, the evolution of the porosity is complex; therefore, we employed a combination of in-situ X-ray tomography and ex-situ metallography to further our understanding of the nature of the porosity. The results of this experimental work show that there are two dominant pore morphologies inside the microwire: continuous central channels and discontinuous off-center crescent-shaped pores. Both morphologies may be observed regardless of the initial diameter of the microwire, but the off-center crescent-shaped pores appear to evolve more significantly during the deposition process and are likely originating from the initial phase transformations. By comparison, the central channels continuously evolve throughout homogenization, acting as a sink for the excess vacancies in the system.

 

In addition to our experimental studies, we undertook a modeling study to understand the fundamental mechanisms of how vacancies, grain boundaries, phase boundaries, and porosity all interact to influence the microstructural evolution. We developed a pair of modeling frameworks in tandem: one from irreversible thermodynamics and one using the phase-field method. The irreversible thermodynamic model provides information about whether a grain or phase boundary can instantaneously separate to form a pore. By comparison, the phase-field model describes the time evolution of a system once porosity has formed. The thermodynamic model indicated that boundaries could separate when there is a discontinuity in the bulk flux of vacancies at the interface. This discontinuity leads to the annihilation of lattice sites, which would tend to nucleate porosity. These pores can then act like free surfaces and further annihilate (or generate) lattice sites, but this reaction is controlled by the mobility of the interface. The phase-field model captures vacancy transport in a manner consistent with the irreversible thermodynamic model, which required us to relax the assumption of local equilibrium at interfaces. Simulations with this model indicated that pores pin interfaces to prevent migration. Simultaneously, in systems with significant porosity, there is an interaction between pores such that larger pores gradually absorb vacancies ejected by smaller pores. As pores become larger, they increasingly become more effective at sinking vacancies.

 

Broader Impact

 

This work has supported the educational and professional development of six Ph.D. and master?s students at Northwestern University and the University of Cincinnati. Additionally, the work supported two postdoctoral scholars at Northwestern University.


Last Modified: 05/12/2021
Modified by: David C Dunand
